DOC.HEAD: Iran Frees 50 Sick, Disabled POWs
Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with prisoners reported released. Pickup 5th pvs, ``It did...''
DOC.TEXT: Iran released 50 ailing or disabled Iraqi prisoners of war Monday to Red Cross representatives as a gesture of good will, Tehran radio reported. It was not clear whether Iraq would reciprocate and release some of the Iranian POWs it holds. An earlier attempt to arrange a formal swap collapsed. The radio said the prisoners were released in Tehran to the Red Cross for eventual repatriation. Tehran radio, monitored in Cyprus, quoted a Foreign Ministry statement as saying the 50 were freed on humanitarian grounds and in response to a request by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. It did not say when Perez de Cuellar made the appeal. But Baghdad last week sent a memorandum to the U.N. chief expressing concern over POWs in Iran after a Red Cross report on Dec. 6 that 22 Iraqis have died in jail. The deaths were attributed to ``heart attacks and relevant diseases,'' but Iraqi media suggested the prisoners might have been tortured to death. The Red Cross has registered 50,000 prisoners held by Iran and more than 19,200 in Iraqi camps. United Nations officials and diplomats estimate the two sides hold about 100,000 POWs between them. The Red Cross secured an agreement to repatriate ailing prisoners immediately after a U.N.-cease-fire halted the war on Aug.20, 1988. The deal collapsed after the repatriation of only 400 disabled and wounded prisoners, with both sides accusing each other of falsifying the number of captives seeking asylum. Angelo Gnadinger, Middle East chief for the Red Cross, visited Tehran and Baghdad last week seeking a swap of the remaining 1,000 wounded and disabled POWs held by both sides. The mediation collapsed, mainly because Tehran insisted the exchange be coupled with a withdrawalof Iraqi forces from chunks of land they occupied in the final weeks of the war. U.N.-sponsored peace talks have been deadlocked mainly over the troop withdrawal issue and Iraq's demand for redrawing the border to give it full sovereignty over the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway. The channel, a confluence of the great Tigris and Euphrates rivers, is Iraq's sole outlet to the Persian Gulf. Before the war, the border ran down the middle of Shatt-Al-Arab.
